title: How to Connect Speakers to an Amp

steps.headline: Install an amp in your vehicle.
steps.description: Find a large area in the back luggage section of your car that can fit an amp. For more compact cars, like a sedan, find a space behind, beneath, or between your back passenger seats to fit the device. As you set up your amp, double-check that 3 long wires are connecting the device to your car speakers.If you’re having trouble installing an amp on your own, talk to a car repair professional for assistance. You can find the supplies you’ll need at an auto shop, or any store that sells mechanical car supplies.

steps.headline: Check that the RCA, speaker, and remote turn-on leads are connected to your amp.
steps.description: Make sure that your car is turned off, then examine the 3 long wires connected to the back of your amp. These leads are essential to your amp functioning properly, and are usually wired when the amp is first installed. Note that these wires are made with special clips, and don’t need to be soldered or adjusted to plug into your amp.These wires may be different colors, depending on the manufacturer. Your speakers should be in the back of your vehicle. If you’re having trouble finding them, consult your car manual or a professional.

steps.headline: Cut out at least 4 sections of speaker wire that can fit in your car.
steps.description: Visit a hardware store or other shop that sells wiring supplies. Purchase several lengths of speaker wire, as these will connect your car speakers to the newly installed amp. Note that these speakers will have black insulation on the outside, and have 1 red and 1 black wire on the inside.Car speakers and amps rely on negative and positive terminals, or power sources, to produce sound. Your speaker wires have 2 segments that can attach to both wires.

steps.headline: Remove 1 cm (0.39 in) of wire coating from both ends of the wires.
steps.description: Use wire cutters or pliers to remove a small section of plastic coating from the ends of each black and red wire. Repeat this process on the opposite end of the speaker wire. Discard the leftover plastic once you’ve removed it from the wire, and make sure that an even amount of bare wire is exposed on both ends.You’ll need to remove the outer black insulation as well as the plastic coating on the 2 inner wires. The red goes with the positive terminal, while the black wire goes with the negative.

steps.headline: Attach heat shrink tubing to the wires.
steps.description: Visit a hardware store and pick up some heat shrink tubing, which essentially looks like a plastic sheath or cover for your wires. Cut a small, 1 in (2.5 cm) section of tubing and slide it over both wires. To secure the tubing to the wire, hover a heat gun at least 3 in (7.6 cm) away from the surface.If you’re unsure about how to use heat shrink tubing, ask a professional for help. Don’t touch or handle the tip of the heat gun when it’s turned on, or you could burn yourself.

steps.headline: Solder metal terminals to the end of your speaker wires.
steps.description: Slide a metal terminal clip onto the end of each exposed wire. Power up your soldering gun, then press the tip of the tool where the clip meets the wire. Repeat this process on all of the terminal clips to make sure they’re connected to the speaker wires.If you aren’t experienced in soldering, try practicing with some scrap wire beforehand. Check online or in a hardware store to see if you can buy wires with the terminals already attached.

steps.headline: Connect 4 speaker wires to right and left inputs on the amp.
steps.description: Search along the back of the amp for at least for multiple sets of terminals. Use a screwdriver to connect the red wires to the positive terminal, and the black wires to the negative terminal. The terminals will latch onto the amp and be held in place by the screws.Check the back of the amp for plus and minus signs, which correspond to the different terminals. Some speaker systems may be arranged differently, depending on the car you have. Keep track of which speakers the wires correspond to. For instance, 1 terminal will power the right front speaker, while another may power the left.

steps.headline: Hook the opposite ends of the wire to your speaker.
steps.description: Look for several sets of binding posts on the back side of your speaker. Twist the outer caps on these plugs to loosen them, then thread the corresponding positive and negative wires through the terminal. Once you’ve threaded the wire through, go ahead and tighten the cap.Follow the color coding on the binding posts, which will help you wire the negative and positive terminals correctly.

steps.headline: Test your car speakers to make sure everything’s connected.
steps.description: Turn on your car like you normally would, and try playing the speakers. See if the music or radio sounds any louder with the new amp connection. If you can’t hear a difference, ask a professional to take a second look at your wiring.

steps.headline: Wire your speakers in a series if they’re less than 8 ohms.
steps.description: Check the back of your speakers to see how many ohms, or electrical resistance, it has. Note that high quality amps may have a resistance of 4 ohms or so, while other speakers may have a different default setting.If you’re having trouble figuring out your speaker settings, check the user manual for help.

steps.headline: Check that your amp and speakers are turned off.
steps.description: Unplug your amps and speakers so no electricity is running through them. Since you’re working with live wires, you don’t want to give yourself a nasty shock!

steps.headline: Attach a wire between the inner terminals on the speaker.
steps.description: Take the wire terminal on the end of your speaker wire and attach it to the negative terminal on the rightmost speaker. Once you’ve done this, attach the opposite end of the wire to the positive terminal on the leftmost speaker.You can use wires with clips or terminals for this. Wires with clips can be purchased online, while terminal connectors need to be soldered manually.Did you know? The right terminal is positive, and the left is negative.

steps.headline: Connect 2 ends of the harness wire into the 2 remaining terminals.
steps.description: Purchase a harness wire that splits in 2 wires on 1 end. Hook the wire clips into the remaining positive and negative terminals to complete the parallel setup.

steps.headline: Secure the jack on the harness wire to your amp.
steps.description: Find the plug for a jack on your amp and attach the corresponding wire. Since you’re working with a harness wire, you don’t need to worry about connecting individual terminals.

steps.headline: Opt for a parallel wiring system if your speakers are more than 8 ohms.
steps.description: Look on the back of your speaker to see what the total ohms reading is. If your speaker has more than an 8 ohms of electrical load, you’ll need to try a different setup to power it successfully.Warning: Always check that your speaker and amp are unplugged before you wire anything!

steps.headline: Use a twisted pair of wires to connect both sets of terminals together.
steps.description: Starting with the rightmost speaker, clip the dual ends of your twisted wire into the positive and negative terminals of the speaker on the right. After you’ve done this, take the other dual ends of wire and plug them into both terminals on the left speaker.Twisted wires are usually 2 differently colored wires bent together. Make sure that each wire color is connecting to the same terminal. For example, the white section of a black and white wire would always connect to the positive terminals.

steps.headline: Attach a separate wire from the both speaker terminals to the amplifier.
steps.description: Take another twisted wire and plug 1 end of the wire into the mono jack behind the positive terminal on the leftmost speaker. Repeat this process by wiring another twisted wire to the jack behind the positive terminal on the left speaker. Connect the ends of both speaker to the positive and negative terminals on your amp to finish the wiring process!
